How small? How frequent? How sudden? ::: ::: {.column width="3%"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - And....How Surprising ! How Shocking! How sad...How Wonderful !!! - So: Our Questions, and our *Surprise* lead us to creating Human Experiences. ::: ::: ## Does this Surprise you? ::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: r-fit-text {{< tweet appadappajappa 1541366922545369088 >}} ::: ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ![](/content/materials/images/toilet.jpg){fig-align="center" height="600"} ::: ::: ## The Element of Surprise? ::: columns ::: {.column width="35%"} ![](/content/materials/images/P&P.jpg) ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: r-fit-text Jane Austen knew a lot about human information processing as these snippets from **Pride and Prejudice** *(published in 1813 -- over 200 years ago)* show : - She was a woman of mean understanding, little *information* , and uncertain temper. - Catherine and Lydia had *information* for them of a different sort. - When this *information* was given, and they had all taken their seats, Mr. Collins was at leisure to look around him and admire,... - You could not have met with a person more capable of giving you certain *information* on that head than myself, for I have been connected with his family in a particular manner from my infancy. - This *information* made Elizabeth smile, as she thought of poor Miss Bingley. - This *information*, however, startled Mrs. Bennet ... - https://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/research/projects/cogaff/misc/austen-info.html ::: ::: ::: ## Claude Shannon and Information ![](/content/materials/images/InfoSurprise.png){fig-align="center" width="1350"} https://plus.maths.org/content/information-surprise ## Human Experience is....Data?? ::: columns ::: {.column width="65%"} {{< youtube sFIDCtRX_-o >}} ::: ::: {.column width="20%"} ![](/content/materials/images/dear-data.jpg) ::: ::: ## Experiments and Hypotheses: A Kitchen Experiment ![](/content/materials/images/DoE.png){fig-alt="Used without permission from https://safetyculture.com/topics/design-of-experiments/" fig-align="center" width="875"} - Inputs are: Ingredients, Recipes, Processes - Outputs are: Taste, Texture, Colour, Quantity!! ## What is the Result of an Experiment? {.smaller} ::: columns ::: {.column width="45%"} - All experiments give us data about phenomena - We obtain data about the things that happen: **Outputs** - What makes things happen?: **Inputs** - How?: **Process** - When? **Factors** - How much "output" is caused by how much "input"? **Effect Size** ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} All Experiments stem from - Human Curiosity, - a Hypothesis, and - a Desire to Find out and Talk about Something ::: ::: ## A Famous Lady and her Famous Experiment ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](/content/materials/images/nightingale.jpeg) ![](/content/materials/images/rose.jpg){fig-align="center" width="400"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: r-fit-text In 1853, Turkey declared war on Russia. After the Russian Navy destroyed a Turkish squadron in the Black Sea, Great Britain and France joined with Turkey. In September of the following year, the British landed on the Crimean Peninsula and set out, with the French and Turks, to take the Russian naval base at Sevastopol. What followed was a tragicomedy of errors -- failure of supply, failed communications, international rivalries. Conditions in the armies were terrible, and disease ate through their ranks. They finally did take Sevastopol a year later, after a ghastly assault. It was ugly business all around. Well over half a million soldiers lost their lives during the Crimean War. ::: ::: ::: ## Florence Nightingale's Data ::: {.cell hash='new_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_b5ff29a093332e0912f682eab705e44d'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ## How Does Data look Like, then? ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](/content/materials/images/Ratio-Interval-Ordinal-Nominal.PNG) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} #### Types of Variables - Using Interrogative Pronouns - Nominal: What? Who? Where? (Factors, *Dimensions*) - Ordinal: Which Types? What Sizes? How Big? (Factors, Dimensions) - Interval: How Often? (Numbers, *Facts*) - Ratio: How many? How much? How heavy? (Numbers, *Facts*) ::: ::: ## Types of Variables in Nightingale Data {.smaller} ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Using Interrogative Pronouns - Nominal: None - Ordinal: (Factors, Dimensions) - HOW? `War, Disease, Other` - Interval: (Numbers, *Facts*) - WHEN? `Year, Month` - Ratio: (Numbers, *Facts*) - HOW MANY? `Rate of Deaths` (War, Disease, Other) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](/content/materials/images/Ratio-Interval-Ordinal-Nominal.PNG) ::: ::: s
